vjdbv0.3_description: GenBank Accession ID of the viral sequence. it equals NCBI Accession, ENA Accession, DDBJ Accession, which are part of the INSDC.
Assembly ID of the sequence (INSDC).
References the BioProject Accession that the viral sequence is a part of (INSDC). Also BioProject id of the host of the prophages
References the BioSample Accession that the viral sequence is a part of (INSDC).
Date when the sample the sequence originates from was collected/sampled.
Country or sea area where the sample the sequence originates from was collected/sampled.
Genbank title of the sequence.
Determines if this sequence is available in Genbank.
Determines if this sequence is a appointed reference sequence in the RefSeq database.
City where the sample the sequence originates from was collected/sampled.
Country name and additional identifier like a state abbreviation from where the sample the sequence originates from was collected/sampled.
Common name of the host the viral sequence was collected from, e.g. human.
Length of the sequence in basepairs (bp).
Molecule type of the sequence, e.g. ssRNA.
Wether the sequence is a partial or complete sequence.
The level of the sequence completeness compare to the representative sequence in refseq in percentage
GenBank organism name, a taxonomic name at species level or below the species level.
Organization the submitter(s) is(are) affiliated with.
Date when the sequence was released into a repository (GenBank, BV-BRC)
Name of the virus segment
NCBI Sequence Read Archive (SRA) accession ID.
Submitter name of the sequence.
Tissue, Specimen or Source of the host from which the sample the sequence originates from was collected/sampled.
State/Region where the sample the sequence originates from was collected/sampled.
ENA analysis object accession.
The level of the Assembly (contig, scaffold, chromosome, complete genome).
Minimum length of consecutive Ns to be considered a gap.
The program used for genome assembly.
Identifier on how to treat the submitted assembly. Currently only assemblies from ‘clone or isolate’ are permitted.
Accession of the sequence in the BV-BRC database.
Name of the institution/affiliation to which the person collecting the sample belongs
Health state of the host at the time of sample collection, e.g. diseased or healthy
The geographic location by latitude, where the sample the sequence originates from was collected/sampled. (DD)
The geographic location by longitude, where the sample the sequence originates from was collected/sampled. (DD)
Continent where the sample the sequence originates from was collected/sampled.
Describes the physical, environmental or local geographical source of the sample, e.g. soil
Name of the person that collected the sample
The cuttoff used to determine if the sample is seropositive.
References an ENA assembly to an ENA Experiment.
Natural behaviour of the sampled host.
The hosts main disease diagnosis.
The hosts disease outcome. Did the host recover from the disease?

The symptoms that have been reported in relation to the illness, such as cough, diarrhea, fever, headache, malaise, myalgia, nausea, runny_nose, shortness_of_breath, sore_throat. If multiple exposures are applicable, please state them separated by semicolon.
The hosts broader group association in a taxonomic context.
Natural habitat of the avian or mammalian host
BVBRC Lab Host, common name of the lab host.
The lab hosts NCBI Taxonomy ID.
The lab hosts scientific species name.
The sampled hosts scientific species name.
The sampled hosts NCBI Taxonomy ID.
The sampled hosts sex.
The sampled hosts unique ID by which it can be referred to.
Method used to assess if a sample if flu positive/negative. When multiple once were used they are seperated by semicolon.
Result of the given methods. Positive(P) or Negative(N). For multiple test the results are delimited by semicolon, e.g. P; P.
Influenza virus type classification, A, B or C.
Determines if this sequence is available in BV-BRC.
The test result for other tested pathogens given as described by influenza test result.
Was the sample tested for other pathogens? Insert the pathogenic organisms using semicolon as a delimiter, e.g. Newcastle. “None” is also valid.
Lineage determined by Pangolin.
Pangolin version used to determine the lineage.
If the sample was only received and not collected provide the receipt date.
RKI Accession of the viral sequence.
References a ENA assembly to an ENA Run object.
The viral species NCBI Taxonomy ID.
Serological variety of a species characterised by its antigenic properties, e.g. H1N1.
Common abbreviations of the viral species name.
temprory NCBI Tax ID used for mapping taxonoly tree to metadata table
Average sequencing depth across the sequence.
Percentage of G and C nucleotides in the sequence.
Percentage of Ns within the whole sequence.
Generic name of the sequence (Name of the entry).
Number of contigs in the sequence.
The doi of the sequences publication paper.
The pubmed ID of the sequences publication paper.
Last update date of the sequence in BVBRC (whole entry).
Version of the sequence (whole entry).
Institution that sequenced the collected sample.
Insert size for paired reads.
Instrument model used for sequencing.
The protocol used to construct the sequencing library.
The design of the sequencing library including details of how it was constructed.
The sequencing library layout specifies whether to expect single or paired configuration of reads.
The name for the sequencing library if any.
The method used to select for or against, enrich, or screen the material being sequenced.
The library source specifies the type of source material that is being sequenced.
The sequencing technique intended for this sequencing library.
Instrument platform used for sequencing, multiple are seperated (only for assemblys)
Why was the collected sample sequenced?
The name of the database where the sequence was originally released.
Country of the submitter's institute.
Country or location of the organization of the submitters.
VirJenDB sequence ID of the viral sequence.
VirJenDB metadata version
Unique ID given by the investigator as strain might not be unique.
Antiviral treatment used for this subject, such as zanamavir oseltamivir, amantadine.
Dosage of the treatment taken by the subject. example: 0.05 mg.
Duration of antiviral treatment after onset of clinical symptoms in days.example: 5.
Initiation of antiviral treatment after onset of clinical symptoms in days. example: 2.5.
The run data file model.
The name or relative pathname of a run data file.
Whether or not the subject is gravid. if so, report date due or date post-conception and specify which of these two dates is being reported.
Was the subject confined to a hospital as a result of virus infection or problems occurring secondary to virus infection?
Other descriptive information relating to the host.
The number of days the illness lasted. example: 4
Date the subject showed an onset of symptoms. format: yyyy-mm-dd. example: 2011-10-20

The symptoms that have been reported in relation to the illness, such as cough, diarrhea, fever, headache, malaise, myalgia, nausea, runny_nose, shortness_of_breath, sore_throat. if multiple exposures are applicable, please state them separated by semicolon.
Unique number of the strain which is reported as a part of the influenza strain name, such as a/chicken/fujian/411/2002(hxn1). format: integer number, example: 411
Date that the influenza vaccination was administered to the subject over the past year. format: yyyy-mm-dd. example: 2007-05-12
Influenza vaccinations that have been administered to the subject over the last year. example: 2009 h1n1 flumist

vjdbv0.3_name: Influenza-like Illness at the Time of Sample Collection
vjdbv0.3_description: Is the subject at the time of sample collection considered to have influenza like illness?
Dose used for the inoculoation experiment.
Brief description of the protocol inoculation route.
Is the virus stock used for the inoculation available?
Does the h1n1 influenza virus originate from a swine-like outbreak (as opposed to a seasonal flu)?
Description helping to explain what the cut off value means.
Number of host individuals inoculated for the experiment.
Use of personal protective equipment, such as gloves, gowns, during any type of exposure. example: mask
Reason for the sample collection.

Conditions at which sample was stored, usually storage temperature, duration and location. in soil context: explain how and for how long the soil sample was stored before dna extraction (fresh/frozen/other).
Free-form text describing the sample, its origin, and its method of isolation.
Designation of information related to vaccination history as self reported or documented.
Name of the strain from which the sample was obtained.
Briefly describes the goals, purpose, and scope of the study.  this need not be listed if it can be inherited from a referenced publication.
Exposure of the subject to infected human or animals, such as poultry, wild bird or swine. if multiple exposures are applicable, please state them separated by semicolon. example: poultry; wild bird

Duration of the exposure of the subject to an infected human or animal. if multiple exposures are applicable, please state their duration in the same order in which you reported the exposure in the field 'subject exposure'. example: 1 day; 0.33 days (Units: year)
Clear and useful title of the study/ project, e.g. a title usable for a publication or the purpose of the project and its timeframe.
Clear and useful title to identify the sequencing experiment. This title will not be submitted to the ENA on submission.
Clear and useful title to identify the sample the sequence originates from was collected/sampled. This title will not be submitted to the ENA on submission.

Setting within which the subject is exposed to animals, such as farm, slaughterhouse, food preparation. if multiple exposures are applicable, please state their type in the same order in which you reported the exposure in the field 'subject exposure'. example: backyard flock; confined animal feeding operation
Dosage of the vaccine taken by the host. example: 0.05 ml
Lot number of the vaccine.
Manufacturer of the vaccine.

vjdbv0.3_name: WHO/OIE/FAO Clade (Required for HPAI H5N1 Viruses)
vjdbv0.3_description: Who/oie/fao clade should be included for highly pathogenic h5n1 viruses. example: 2.2
Collection of outdated names for a particular virus.
Byte range data of the sample in the sequence file without the header
The file location of the multiseq fasta file including the parent folder name
Date of the insertion into the VirJen database
The last date the metadata was updated in the VirJen database.
A 'Realm' is the highest taxonomic rank into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Subrealm' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Kingdom' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Subkingdom' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Phylum' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Subphylum' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Class' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Subclass' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Order' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'suborder' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Family' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Subfamily' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Genus' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Subgenus' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.

A Species is the lowest taxonomic rank in the hierarchy approved by the ICTV. While subspecies levels of classification may exist for some viruses (e.g. Hepatitis C virus), the ICTV does not classify viruses below the species level. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Realm' is the highest taxonomic rank into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Subrealm' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Kingdom' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Subkingdom' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Phylum' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Subphylum' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Class' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Subclass' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Order' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'suborder' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Family' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Subfamily' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Genus' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Subgenus' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.

A Species is the lowest taxonomic rank in the hierarchy approved by the NCBI. While subspecies levels of classification may exist for some viruses (e.g. Hepatitis C virus), the NCBI does not classify viruses below the species level. Defined by the NCBI.

The genotype or subtype of a viral sequence, as provided by the sequence submitter. This field comes from the "/serotype" field of the GenBank record and is showns as submitted. Consistency and accuracy may vary.
Individual isolate from which the sample was obtained
Host age given by a number. Is connected to Host Age Unit. The number should match the unit. E.g. 2 years
Unit that describes the host age. Is connected to Host Age. Should fit the number, e.g. 2 years
Host Ages in a uniform unit, tba
Host Age and Unit.
Indicator that sequences came from samples from a laboratory setting, and not from a wild host.
BVBRC NCBI TaxIDs of the lineage
Aggregation of the NCBI Taxonomy Names of the virus lineage.
Aggregation of the ICTV Taxonomy Names of the virus lineage.
This accession was used to define a species in the ICTV Taxonomy.
There is one page in Viralzone for this Taxon ID
The ICTV Host source field content to be combined with other host group data from the other sources.
ICTV ID from Master_Species_List file
Commonly used virus name (or names separated by a semi-colon).
Host Age and Unit.

vjdbv0.3_name: Hash content for the rank in taxonomy tree

vjdbv0.3_description: A flag that indicates if the record is the latest update in VirJenDB database
The list of the fields and their content when they are updated in each release in compare to the previous version
Clear and useful title to identify the analysis of your sequencing experiment. This title will not be submitted to the ENA on submission.
If the sequence is a representative for a group of identical sequences.
The VirJenDB Accession for the unique representative sequence. Usually the smallest Accession in the group.
If the sequence is a representative sequence of a group of sequences, computed by VClust.
VirJenDB Accession of the representative of its cluster
The tool or database that predicted the sequence. No value means that there it is not a predicted Sequence.
Host Accession ID from the GenBank that can refer to the host sequence (not the prophage)
